with little response. About this
time, the Irish resorted to the
questionable expedient of helping
Germany, and the rebellion of
1916 was the result. Although
the Sinn Fein had not been sole
leaders of the 'revolt, they sprang
into prominence and power over
night because of their past efforts in the same direction. After
the revolt, Ireland was divided
into three parties; the people
Ulster, favoring close union with
the Empire the Sinn Fein, favoring complete independence,
and a modern group, favoring a
loose union with the Empire and
liberal home rule-: The Irish coul,i
come to no -agreement amon-,
themselves, and a convention to
settle the matter produced no results.
'In= 1918, the Sinn- Fein carried
all the elections except those in
Ulster. In 1919, the "Irish Republic" was declared to exist.
Guerilla warfare started almost :It
once, and, because of England's
leniency, spread beyond control.
The regular police force suffered
so many casualties that they were
replaced by the "Black and Tans'
